title: Quantify permeability using on-a-chip models in high-throughput applications
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Loading and extracting data
Timing: 30 min
The purpose of this step is to quantify the fluorescence intensity from the images acquired during the BI assay. It is performed in the Open-source FIJI software where data (images) are loaded, and raw data, as fluorescence intensity, are extracted to be used in the next step to quantify the Papp.
Note: To download the open-source software use this link https://fiji.sc/#download[href=https://fiji.sc/#download].
Open FIJI software and load the images acquired in the step before.
Go to the directory where the data are stored.
Sort the data by “Date” by clicking on column heading (just below the address bar) label “Date”. The small blue arrow in the column heading should point upward (Sorting oldest to newest).
Select all the data by clicking Ctrl + A and drag them into FIJI.
Critical: Pay attention while loading the images that they follow the right order. For more information check problem 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec7.3].
Note: in total in our example there are 210 images (30 chips, 1 dye, 7 timepoints).
Organize images into a stack (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2376-Fig3.jpg
Figure 3. Organize images into a stack
(A) Access from the menu to open “Image to stack” step 2.a.
(B) Fill in the “Image to Stack” menu step 2.b.
(C) Single images will get concatenate in one stack step 2.c.
(D) Scroll bar in the bottom- left part of the stack window step 2.d.
(E) Information about number of images and label of the image visualized in the stack are in the top-left part of the stack window (steps 2.d.i and 2.d.ii).
In the menu bar of FIJI select Image > Stacks > Images to Stack (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]A).
In the “Image to Stack” menu fill in or tick on (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]B):

“Name”: choose a suitable name for the file.
“Use Titles as labels”: tick on.
Select “ok”.
The stack will be created (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]C).
Inspect the stack:
Information about the stack and the chip visualized in the stack, are shown in the top left corner of the stack window. The total number of images in the stack (210) and the image currently visualized in the stack (1) are indicated with “c: 1/210”. Next to it there is the label of the image express as “chip_dye_timepoint” (B02_W2_TP1 in Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]D).
By scrolling the scroll bar (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]E), at the bottom of the stack, it is possible to change the image visualized.
Optional: Change the order of the images in case is needed. In the menu bar select Image → Stacks → Tools → Stack Sorter.
Convert the stack into an hyperstack (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]). In the hyperstack, chips and timepoints are indicated as slices (z = 30), and frames (t = 7), respectively.
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2376-Fig4.jpg
Figure 4. Convert the stack into an hyperstack (step 3)
(A) Access the menu to open the “Stack to Hyperstack” option (step 3.a).
(B) Fill in the “Convert to Hyperstack” menu with the appropriate number of channels (step 3.b) (c), slices (z) and frames (t).
(C) The stack is transformed in hyperstack (step 3.c).
(D) Scroll bars in the bottom- left part of the hyperstack window (step 4.a).
(E) Information about c, z, t and label of the image are in the top-left part of the hyperstack window (step 4.b).
In the menu bar select Image > Hyperstacks > Stack to Hyperstack… (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]A).
In the “Convert to Hyperstack” menu (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]B).

Select “Order” based on how the images are ordered (xyctz). In the example reported the order is dyes (c), timepoints (t) and chips (z) (i.e., N23_W2_TP1, N23_W2_TP2;… N23_W2_TP7, N20_W2_TP1…..N20_W2_TP7).
Fill in with the number of channels (c), slices (z), frames (t). The product c × z × t has to be equal to the number of images in the stack (c = 1, z = 30, t = 7, 1 ∗ 30 ∗ 7 = 210 images).
Select “ok”
The hyperstack will be generated (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]C).
Inspect the hyperstack.
In the bottom of the hyperstack window (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]D) there are two scroll bars, check from the top to the bottom, that each scroll bar contains the correct image:
“Z” scroll bar: to change the chip visualized in the hyperstack (30 chips).
“imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2376-Fx4.jpg” scroll bar: to change the timepoint visualized in the hyperstack (7 TPs).
Note: in case there are multiple channels a third scroll bar will be present: “C” scroll bar: to change the dye visualized in the hyperstack wondow (2 dyes).
In the top left corner of the hyperstack window (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]E) there are information about the hyperstack and the image currently visualize in the window (z: 1/30 t: 1/7 in Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]E) and label of chip visualized ((B02_W2_TP2) in Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]E).
z: 1/30 t: 1/7 indicate that there are 30 chips (z) and 7 timepoints (t) and that the image visualized in the window is the first timepoint of the first chip label as B02_W2_TP1.
Align the images in the hyperstack (Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2376-Fig5.jpg
Figure 5. Align images in the hyperstack (step 5)
(A) Open the align plugin (step 5.a).
(B) Fill in the information to run the alignment (step 5.b).
(C) Press “ok”

(D) Select an area which will be used by the plugin to align all the images (step 5.d).
In the menu bar select Plugins → Template Matching → Align slices in Stack… (Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]A).
In the “Align slices in stack” menu select “ok” (Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]B):
The matching method should be left at the default (Normalized correlation coefficient) but can be adjusted for specific scenarios. For more information see: https://sites.google.com/site/qingzongtseng/template-matching-ij-plugin[href=https://sites.google.com/site/qingzongtseng/template-matching-ij-plugin].
Optional: Adjust the Search area (pixels around ROI) value. The value should be set based on the drift observed in the images. If there is a large drift present in the images this value could be between 50–80 pixels. Usually about 30 should suffice.
An “Align slices” message will pop-up select “ok”.
Select a region, in the image, which includes the bended part of the microfluidic chip (Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]C) and the alignment will be performed.
Check that the images are aligned. See Figure 16[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig16] for representative image of when the alignment fails or succeed.
Note: In case there is a large drift between images and the alignment fails check problem 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec7.5].
Quantify fluorescence intensity in donor and receiver channel (Figure 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2376-Fig6.jpg
Figure 6. Quantify fluorescence intensities in donor and receiver channel (step 6)
(A) Select the type of measurement to run (step 6.a).
(B) Load the ROI supplemented with this protocol (step 6.b.i), place the ROI above the phaseguide to select donor and open ROI manager (step 6.b.iii).
(C) Place the ROI below the phaseguide to select receiver area to use for the quantification (step 6.b.vi).
(D) Run the quantification (step 9.c).
(E) Example of how the results measured is shown (step 6.c.iv).
Select the measurement required for the analysis (Figure 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6]A).
In the menu bar select Analyze > Set Measurements…

Tick on: “Mean gray value”, “Stack position, “Display label”, and select “ok”.
Select the area of interest (ROI) in the donor and receiver channel (Figures 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6]B and 6C).
Open the ROI file supplemented with this protocol, by dragging in it in FIJI menu bar.
A rectangle in the image in the hyperstack will pop-up (Figure 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6]B).
Note: In case a different magnification is used during the acquisition of the images in step 8, adjust the ROI accordingly.
Move the ROI above the PhaseGuide. This ROI is used to quantify fluorescence intensity of the donor.
Note: while locating the ROI zoom-in on the PhaseGuide to make sure it is excluded.
In the menu bar select Analyze > Tools > ROI Manager…
In the “ROI manager” menu Select “Add [t]” and “ROI_BI” will appear in the window (Figure 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6]B).
Move the ROI below the PhaseGuide This ROI is used to quantify fluorescence intensity of the receiver (Figure 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6]C).
Note: while locating the ROI zoom-in on the PhaseGuide to make sure it is excluded.
In the “ROI manager” menu Select “Add [t]” and a second “ROI_BI” will appear in the window.
Relabel both ROIs, the first one as “ROI_BI_donor”, “ROI_BI_receiver”.
Measure the fluorescence intensities in the ROI of the receiver and donor and for all the images in the hyperstack (Figure 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6]D).
In the “ROI manager” window select both ROIs.
In the “ROI manager” menu select More > Multi Measurement.
In the “Multi Measure” menu tick on: Measure all 210 slices; One row per slice; select “ok”.
The “Results” panel will appear (Figure 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6]E), save the file as csv by selecting File > Save as…> csv file.

Note: The file contains 6 columns, a progressive number, the hyperstack label, the mean gray values (Mean) of the donor and the receiver, information about the timepoint (Frame) per each input/image.
Papp curve fitting calculation
Timing: 10 min
The purpose of this step is to use the curve fitting approach to quantify Papp in HT study, for leaky barrier or permeable molecules. In this step make use of the excel template file Papp_curve fitting, supplemented with this protocol.
Set-up excel software for analysis (Figure 7[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig7]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2376-Fig7.jpg
Figure 7. Set-up excel software (step 7)
(A) Open Excel Option (step 7.a).
(B) Enable Solver Add-in to compute and find the best K and D (step 7.c).
In the excel menu bar select File > Option > Add-ins (Figure 7[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig7]A).
In the “Add-ins” window select “Go” (Figure 7[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig7]B).
In the “Add-ins” menu tick on “Solver Add-in” and select “ok” (Figure 7[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig7]B).
In the excel menu bar in Data, Solver symbol will appear.
Load the data in the excel template file Papp_curve fitting (Figure 8[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig8]A).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2376-Fig8.jpg
Figure 8. Load data and calculate Y fit and chi square (from steps 8.b.i to 9)
(A) Fill in with the BI data the sheet in the excel template file.
(B) Function used to calculate the intensity ratio between fluorescence intensities of receiver and donor + receiver (Y), to fit the experimental BI data (Fit) and to calculate the chi square. For more information on how to derive and quantify Y and fit see Equations 7[href=https://www.wicell.org#fd7] and 8[href=https://www.wicell.org#fd8].
Open the template file label “Curve fitting Papp.xlsx”.
Fill in with the data generated in step 6.c.iii.
In a (below red arrow in Figure 8[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig8]A cells B23:B29) with timepoints express in minute.
In b (below blue arrow in Figure 8[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig8]A cells D23:D29) with donor fluorescence intensities.

In c (below green arrow in Figure 8[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig8]A cells F23:F29) with receiver fluorescence intensities.
As initial guess set K (cell N22) and D (cell N23) equal to 1 (below yellow arrow in Figure 8[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig8]A).
Calculate Y (cells H23:H29), fit (cells I23:I29) and chi square (cells J23:J29) (Figure 8[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig8]B).
Fit the data to quantify the Papp (Figure 9[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig9]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2376-Fig9.jpg
Figure 9. Fit the data (step 10)
(A) Hoe to open the Solver function in the excel menu (step 10.a).
(B) Appropriate parameters to fill in the “Solver” menu (step 10.b).
In the menu bar select Data > Solver (Figure 9[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig9]A).
In the “Solver Parameters” menu fill with these parameters (Figure 9[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig9]B):
“Set Object”: $N$24.
“To”: Min.
“By changing Variable Cells”: $N$22:$N$23.
Tick on “Make Unconstrained Variables Non-Negative”.
Select a Solving Methos: “GRG Nonlinear”.
Select “Solve”.
Papp is calculated in cell N26 [cm/s] (Figures 8[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig8]A and 10[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig10]A).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2376-Fig10.jpg
Figure 10. Papp calculation (step 11)
(A) function used to calculate the Papp and sum chi square.
(B) Graph generated by plotting fluorescence intensity of donor (blue dots) and receiver (green dots) channel overtime on the left and on the right experimental data (blue dots) and the fit (red line) obtained with the solver Add-ins (step 13).
Experimental intensities of the donor and receiver are plotted overtime in graph on the left in Figure 10[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig10]B.
Note: Check that neither the intensities of the receiver or the donor decreases overtime. Otherwise exclude that chip. To prevent this issue, pay attention while performing the BI assay. For more information check problem 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec7.1].
Ratio (receiver/donor) of experimental fluorescence intensities and fitted ones are plotted overtime in the graph in Figure 10[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig10]B.
Check the goodness of the fit. Red line should fit all data points.
Duplicate the sheet and repeat the process from steps 8–13.a with data from other chips.
